title: I do not believe that theists truly respect the beliefs of others

author: JustforReddit99101
text:
With homosexuals I am against using the state to make laws against it particularly for that reason. Its a sin but you got to use discernment, it is two consenting adults no crime is commited.


With abortion the women is literally ending her own pregnancy, killing her offspring. So a life is being taken. So I dont care about what you believe I want the state to take action against it.


Its similar to if you worshiped baal or molech and sacrificed your born infant to your God. I dont really care what you believe but you cant sacrifice your children as a form of worship.

author: Emoooooly
text: And I believe that the person carrying the child has a right to choose to not carry that child to term and birth it. I don't care what you believe, I want the state to take action and protect that right.

author: Daderklash
text:
You're making a claim of belief not fact. Lots of people believe a fetus has a right to life, some do not. It's not really objective (as of yet) whether the differences between a fetus and a baby are relevant include or exclude the right to life.

So if I want an abortion, because I think it is morally permissible and the state stops me from having one, that is an infringement and a disrespect to my beliefs

author: JustforReddit99101
text: Well you are disrespecting and infringing on your babies rights so I am cool with that. Also a fetus is anything from 9 weeks till birth. Do fetus's magically gain rights when they exit the birth canal? Why or why not? If not, when do they gain human rights?

author: Daderklash
text: Don't know, neither do you.

author: Daderklash
text:
The point is, even if I was pro life, and I got pregnant, I could choose to carry it to term, because that's part of my belief system. But I haven't a leg to stand on to conclusively say that the fetus has a right to life, so I don't really have a right to tell someone else that they can not have an abortion.

I would have to find some sort of argument that the fetus actually does have a right to life, and so far we haven't had any conclusive arguments

author: JustforReddit99101
text:
Fetus is 9 weeks till birth. Are you saying that 9 month pregnant women we can just kill the baby at will because its a fetus still? No? If not when does it gain the right to life?

The zygote formed at conception has fully formed DNA that makes a unique person a person genetically. That and a positive pregnancy diagnosis is a solid case that its a human life with rights.

Many pro choicers agree that its a human life with rights but they believe the right to bodily autonomy allows the mother to end it at will.

author: Cowboys929395
text:
No one is arguing for late term abortions.  Those are the exceptions and typically involve very emotional choices for the mother because late term abortions are done when there are significant health risks.  Nearly 90% of all abortions are done within 12 weeks, and 66% of those are within 8 weeks.

It's time to get away from the absurd argument about people killing 9 month old babies.  No one is arguing for that.

author: DAMO238
text:
If I believe that all chocolate cakes have lives, and eating them is murder, are you obligated to refrain from eating chocolate cake? If course not, because you would say that the chocolate cake does not have a life, and thus you will continue to eat chocolate cake whenever you please.

This is the same situation, but with a fertilised egg instead. Just because you believe it has a life, does not mean that everyone has to abide by those rules. We see other places where these lines are blurred, such as terminally ill patients that are in a coma. Letting them die, as sad as it is for the family, will free up beds for others who might be more lucid or have a chance to recover. Such topics are debated at length, and choices are usually on case by case basis based on what the individual and the family believe/want.

author: JustforReddit99101
text:
We are not talking about a food item, we are talking about a positive pregnancy diagnosis. Human zygotes should have rights and be treated as human because it is a positive pregnancy diagnosis with fully formed DNA that makes a unique person.


Dehumanizing the offspring and pregnancy is a common tactic of pro choice. A lot of seasoned pro choice dont do that but I do feel if we really focus on a pregnancy is a human life in school that a lot more people would be pro life.

author: DAMO238
text: You see, I don't hold the same view about the zygotes having lives and thus rights, yet you would force this restriction on me? You dismiss the idea of the cake having a life so readily, but what if I truly did believe that the cake has a life. How would you feel if I forced you to stop eating cake because of beliefs you don't hold?

author: JustforReddit99101
text:
Does a cake have fully formed DNA that genetically determines everything about being human? No its a food item. Does a cake only happen in a positive pregnancy diagnosis? No its a food item.


If its not a human life when exactly does it become a human life? It must be sometime in the womb right we dont magically gain rights when we exit the birth canal. So there is that dilemma too with your view.


If you are strongly convicted enough to impose the will of the state on me over a food item, go for it buddy. Thats all I have to say to that. But it is just a dehumanization tactic.


Let me ask if you saw it as a human life would you be against abortion and would you want the state to enforce it? Why or why not?

author: thiswaynotthatway
text:
Why did it matter that its a "fully formed dna"? A tumor had its own unique and fully formed dna too, are we going to get bounty hunters to punish doctors who remove those too? It's still human dna and is a "human life".

A zygote isn't any more a human than the semen I discarded this morning or my wife's egg she menstruated last week, do we need to be punished for that? Their dna was no less "fully formed", be consistent!

Most Christians didn't even make this a part of their religion until their politicians told them to, your strongly held belief was implanted for no reason but to be a wedge issue and you're happy to punish women and doctors and people who only want to help women just because Newt Gingrich and Jerry Falwell told you to, not God.

author: DAMO238
text:
I think you are missing my point. I am not claiming that the cake has a life, since we both know it doesn't. I am using an object that you would claim doesn't have a life, so you can see abortion laws from a pro-choice perspective.

That being said, I will answer your question about whether I would want to prevent abortions if I believe the zygote has a life. I would, firstly, make sure to use contraception myself, to mitigate the risk of unwanted pregnancies and promote the use contraception to others. Let's say despite this, I find myself in the position where I need to make a choice between an abortion or keeping the child, unless it would risk the mother's life, I would promote keeping the child. However, I would not want the state to enforce this belief, since I understand that not everyone holds this opinion, and thus, this should be a personal choice.

Another thing to consider in this case, is also the wellbeing of the mother. Even if I believe the zygote has a life, killing it may still be the more admirable option if keeping it could severely harm the mother, which in turn would hurt the child in the long run.

Now, I ask you the same question but in reverse. If you saw the zygote as without a life, would you still be against abortion and would you still want the state to enforce a ban on abortions? Why or why not?

PS: I need to sleep now, but will get back to you in a few hours time if you respond.

author: JustforReddit99101
text:
No if I viewed it as an unhuman clump of cells of course I wouldnt be against abortion.

What do you mean serious risk to the mother? Unclear. I am pro abortion only to save the mothers life, and thats purely physical. I dont believe in mental reasons for abortion.

Having some experience with mental health, I would be for medicating the women if she desperately needs it, IE having a major episode of like skitzo or something. If there is a safer for the baby option in medications I would prefer that, but if you have to risk the baby go for it.


Thats not the same thing as aborting it though. Its important to recognize the difference and unfortunately laws can sometimes get in the way of that.
